moves.1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2: A rather passive approach to the Caro-Kann.
moves.3... dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7: Black also plays a quiet move. Neither player is willing to open the game up yet.
moves.5... Ngf6 6. Ng5: Attacking the weak point at KB7. Deep Blue used the same Knight move against an exhausted Garry Kasparov in a Caro-Kann to win the decisive Game 6 of the second match, thus making a computer World Champion. Humans have, as yet, been unable to reclaim that mantle.
moves.6... e6 7. Qe2 Nb6: Preparing to drive the advanced White Knight.
moves.8. Bd3 h6 9. Ng5f3: The scene appears utterly pacific. Black should focus on keeping the game closed and getting his King into safety.
moves.9... c5: A strategic error. White has the initiative and can exploit the opening up of the game better than Black.
moves.10. dxc5 Nbd7 11. b4 b6: I would think that 11... B-K2, preparing 12... O-O, would be a better plan. With the game opening up, Black needs to get his King out of the center.
moves.13... Qc7: Getting the Q out of immediate danger. However...
moves.14. Qxe6+: ...this move is decisive. Black resigns, as the Q cannot be captured [14... PxQ 15 B-N6 mate] and interposing doesn't solve the problem [14... B-K2 15 QxB mate].
